div.p: Greetings. Yesterday, shortly after 3 in the evening, the most illustrious man and half of my soul, Mr. Peter Martyr, departed from this world.

He lay ill for barely 8 full days; on the same day that the illness, which now almost everyone suffers from, seized him, he returned his soul to God on the 7th day thereafter. He died sitting in a chair, and I stood by him as he was dying.
His faith in God was most firm.

From the time he returned from France, he always suffered from nausea at food; ulcers also appeared on his shins. He would have preferred to respond to Brentius; but since God willed otherwise, he willingly surrendered himself to God.

How much grief and sorrow I have conceived from the death of this most friendly man, in whom the school and church have suffered an irreparable loss, I can hardly say, and unless I knew that Christ lives and holds the wounds and sores of the church and the seven stars in his hand, I would wish myself dead. But let what is seen by my Savior be done.
Pray for us, for our school and church, that the Lord may provide for us in such a scarcity of learned and experienced men and true theologians. Calvin is also ill, who wrote to me from his bed, etc.

As I was returning home and had just closed the eyes of my friend and sewn his dear body in a linen cloth with tears, behold, your letters are offered to me, wounding my soul with a new wound. But what shall I say, my Fabricius? I see that your complaint is not unjust, nor can I entirely prevent you from leaving. I will only say that your piety should consider whether your departure can heal all those wounds or not make them worse. I sincerely pray to the Lord that he himself may heal your wounds and ours, which are not dissimilar to yours.

The already very grave pain is increased by a persistent rumor, which today has spread here from I know not where, that Rouen was twice attacked in vain with great loss to the Guise's forces, 5 English banners entered, which, when another 5 wanted to follow, were cut down; the Guises, encouraged by the slaughter, attacked the city again for the third time and suffered a huge defeat, but finally, with wicked perseverance, they captured it and slaughtered everyone in the city without distinction. Whether this is true or false, I cannot say; I certainly fear greatly.
Let us pray to the Lord to have mercy on us.
Now SÃ¼lerus returns what he received from you to be returned.

I give you immortal thanks and pray that you continue thus. I will inspect if I have anything earlier, I will send it back to you and will also think about how to repay you. I give thanks to Mr. Belinchetto, your brother, whom you will greet, and note that on January 3rd, a common Swiss day will be held in Baden, mainly because of the Glarus people. Aman Tschudi travels from Glarus to Rapperswil, Saela.
Farewell well and pray to the Lord for us, from whom comes all good, all wisdom, all strength. November 13, 1562.
To the most excellent man Mr. Johannes Fabricius, minister of the church in Chur, esteemed and beloved lord and brother. Chur.
